metadata.case_name: J. K. Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd. v. Labour Appellate Tribunal of India & Ors.

facts.text: A number of thefts of Dhoties had taken place in the Mill.
Management of J. K. Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd. lost confidence in the honesty of the Watch and Ward Staff.
Management decided to terminate services of all persons of the Watch and Ward Staff and recruit fresh men from employment exchange, paying 12 days wages in lieu of notice per Standing Order No. 17A.

Employers Association of Northern India, Kanpur, on behalf of J. K. Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd., made application under clause 5(a) of Government order dated March 10, 1948 (amended May 15, 1948) to the Board, praying for award entitling termination of services of Watch and Ward Staff listed in Annexure A.
During pendency before Board, applicant withdrew prayer as regards 5 workmen.

Inquiry pending before Conciliation Officer since order dated July 9, 1949 directing Labour Commissioner or nominated Conciliation Officer to restart adjudication between J. K. Cotton Weaving Mills Co. and dismissed employee S. N. Shukla, with extensions to September 30, 1950 (validated by U.P. Act XXIII of 1953).

Board rejected preliminary objection on jurisdiction, held not in interests of parties or industry to continue 27 sepoys, awarded permission to terminate with compensation (15 days full wages plus graduated scale).
Both parties appealed to Industrial Court.

Industrial Court agreed on jurisdiction, noted defective procedure (no application to Regional Conciliation Officer), on merits upheld loss of confidence, directed termination per Standing Orders without extra compensation.

Workmen appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, which held application under cl. 5(a) not maintainable relying on Kanpur Mill Mazdoor Union v. Employers Association of Northern India, set aside awards of Board and Industrial Court.
Company filed writ petition under Art. 226 to Allahabad High Court for certiorari quashing Tribunal order.
Mr. Justice Chaturvedi held application maintainable but dismissed for undue delay.
Letters Patent Appeal (Special Appeal No. 205 of 1954) dismissed on preliminary objection that records in Calcutta beyond High Court reach; certificate under Art. 132 and 133(1)(c) issued.
Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal directly against Tribunal order.

legal_issues.text: Whether an application under cl. 5(a) of the Government Order is maintainable for proposed termination of services when an inquiry is pending before a Conciliation Officer within the meaning of cl. 23.
Whether an industrial dispute comes into existence as soon as an employer decides on the dismissal of workmen and proposes to give effect to such decision.

petitioner_arguments.text: Application under cl. 5(a) is maintainable even when inquiry pending under cl. 23; apply harmonious construction to hold cl. 23 has no application when order made on application under cl. 5(a), avoiding incongruity where employer could be penalized despite Board permission.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Cl. 5(a), cl. 23, cl. 24, cl. 26 of Government Order; harmonious construction

petitioner_arguments.text: Industrial dispute arises even at stage employer proposes dismissal, as contemplated non-employment.

respondent_arguments.text: Application under cl. 5(a) not maintainable when inquiry pending; cl. 23 bars discharge without permission of Regional Conciliation Officer.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Cl. 5(a), cl. 23 Government Order; Kanpur Mill Mazdoor Union v. Employers Association of Northern India (1952 I LLJ 195)

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of Government Order provides two modes under cl. 5(a) and 5(b) for commencement of proceedings, but cl. 23 specially bars discharge during pending inquiry/appeal without Conciliation Officer permission, with heavy penalties under cl. 26.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cl. 23 made to prevent fresh disputes when one pending.

court_reasoning.text: Assuming industrial dispute arises on employer's proposal to dismiss, allowing cl. 5(a) application would make cl. 23 dead letter; harmonious construction requires cl. 5(a) applies except where cl. 23 applies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: To harmonise is not to destroy; every part of order has purpose.

court_reasoning.text: General provisions (cl. 5(a)) yield to special provisions (cl. 23); specific prevails over general in same instrument.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited Pretty v. Solly and others.

court_reasoning.text: Inquiry pending on June 13, 1950 before Conciliation Officer; cl. 23 applied, cl. 5(a) not entertainable.

holdings.text: Cl. 5(a) has no application where special provisions of cl. 23 are applicable; employer cannot take advantage of cl. 5(a) when inquiry pending.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held application under cl. 5(a) not maintainable as cl. 23 applied due to pending inquiry; upheld Labour Appellate Tribunal order setting aside awards of Board and Industrial Court; dismissed both appeals.

key_quotes.text: "the rule making authority in making this rule was anxious to prevent as far as possible the recrudescence of fresh disputes between employers and workmen when some dispute was already pending"
key_quotes.speaker: court
